2.author: Separate-Cream7685
2.body:
Yes, people make jokes about ALL agents lying, but in reality they don’t really lie about offers, they risk losing a real client and it’s their commission that’s at risk. Those few thousands extra might be £50 extra for the agent, but if it takes him 4 months longer to achieve that, it’s a really bad deal.

As I said, the only certainty you have and the only that matters is the price you’d be happy to pay for that place. If it’s your dream house, that price will be closer to your maximum, if it’s alright but not special, it might be towards the lower end. Other offers and potential lies won’t change one bit.

Find out if the place you are looking at (it is one place, right?) is available, no point offering if conveyancing has started.

If it is, submit an offer, in writing, and ask for acceptance/rejection within 5 working days.

That’s all, really.

What exactly are you trying to achieve? No agent will give you ALL the information required to enable you to only offer sloghtly above the best, that’s not how reality works.

2.author: T43EIF
2.body: Appreciate the advice. I've had an agent request a higher offer and then not even get back to me. I've also had an agents not even request a higher offer and just sold the property without seeing if I'd increase first. I've lost faith in them honestly.

2.author: Separate-Cream7685
2.body: They can probably “smell” you, they know who’s playing games and who’s not. As I said, make a solid first time offer based on what you want to pay for the place, not based on other offers, and you should be ok.

2.author: T43EIF
2.body: I know what you mean by that, but I've sent them my agreement in principle and offered decent offers (I think?). I think 10k less than what is being asked isn't a low ball? But anyhow, ill just have to keep my fingers crossed i guess

2.author: Separate-Cream7685
2.body: If you offer £10k less and they ghost you, it means others are offering closer to asking price. Why the £10k reduction other than “why not”?

Do you have a job? Speak to people at work more, see if any of them have things in common with you on which to build a friendship.

16.author: DeviousBeevious
16.body:
Okay, as I say you can block me or stop responding. I won't keep pestering you. but I feel ethically obligated to try.

"someone" is the word I use because to me there is no great difference between other animals and humans. There certainly isn't between a dog and a pig, for example. 

The emotional connection you have to pets demonstrates that pets have the ability to have deep emotional bonds and pigs especially are more intelligent than dogs and have the ability to form those same deep, emotional bonds. they can recognize and remember feelings towards individual humans. they have personalities. they morn their dead and show deep distress when their children are taken away from them.

If you couldn't do that to a dog why can you do it to a pig?

16.author: Maetras
16.body:
I care about dogs but I don’t care about pigs, that’s why. Never had any attachment to them. If it helps, I don’t really eat much pork.

And no I don’t intend to block you you’re not annoying me. Although if I stop replying it’ll be because the convo is going in circles.

16.author: DeviousBeevious
16.body:
Okay, to avoid the circles I'll take this opportunity to do some research. I'm interested in whether you had much exposure to farm animals as a child? did you grow up in a rural or urban environment? did you have any pets as a child and if so what species were they?

I'm thinking about what might be good research questions to ask to try and identify why certain people have more sympathy / empathy towards animals than others.

16.author: Maetras
16.body:
I had chickens I kept for eggs when I lived in the middle of the countryside. One of them had a name. They lived out their lives in a big enclosure until the foxes got them or died of old age.

Mostly rural upbringing.

I’ve always had pets: dogs, rabbits and Guinea pigs. Would not eat any of those species pets or not.

I will eat beef, chicken and pork. Possibly lamb but only a few times in my life. I see them as food and don’t have any personal attachment to them. I don’t think I eat any other meat. As for fish, it’s not my favourite but the usual ones.

16.author: DeviousBeevious
16.body:
Thanks for the feedback. the rabbits as pets and resultant not wanting to eat the species as a whole is quite interesting considering that in the UK some people DO eat rabbit. 

This leads me to wonder if keeping pigs, cows or sheep as pets as a child (or perhaps even if you now did as an adult) would cause you to not eat them.

The chickens didn't have that effect presumably as you kept them as a "food animal".

I wonder if there is a way to get children to meet and bond with these animals at a young enough age that they can never see them as food?

That was certainly the case for me with some species like cows. I spent several years regularly being on a cattle farm due to my school friend's family running it and saw their full life cycle and got to know the individual cows and to interact with them. 

As I say though it was the mockumentary Carnage by Simon Amstell that made me finally make the switch to vegan from vegetarian.

16.author: Maetras
16.body:
Actually, I grew up in France so you’d always see rabbit in supermarkets. Always used to comment about it.

I don’t think my views on pigs, cows or sheep would change as a result of keeping them as a child. I’m sure it would affect some other people’s views though. I kept chickens but I still eat and love chicken. I didn’t eat the chickens I kept. They lived outside as a group of 6 and laid eggs.

As for pushing children to become vegan I firmly believe it’s an individual’s choice to eat what they want aka not forced by parents. If spending time around animals at a young age causes them to personally not see them as food then all the rights to them. However, if it doesn’t then all the rights to them too. It’s their right to come to a decision of their own without any big pressures.

I don’t like being forced ideals onto me be it religion, other beliefs or veganism et al. I find that annoying. It’s like people in Oxford street saying on a megaphone “Jesus loves you” or “Jesus died for our sins”. 

As for documentaries on the farm industry, they do present truths but also show too much bias resulting in some inaccuracies and sensationalisation.

16.author: DeviousBeevious
16.body:
If you are arguing people get the right to choose their own morals, then that could lead to people choosing to believe it's okay to go around murdering people, or performing genital mutilation because "it's part of my religion to cut things off of babies". 

I personally do not support people being allowed to come to their own decisions where those decisions cause a large amount of harm. 

I don't especially want to be vegan, it makes my life more difficult, but morally I do not have a choice. I cannot justify causing more suffering than is strictly necessary for survival.

just FYI I probably wont reply again today due to work and other things. thanks for the replies though it's been very helpful.

Anyway, I’ll leave you to it. Take care

TO YOU eating animals is okay because you don't care about it. TO ME it's a HUGE problem.

Thank you for the link kind sir.

18.author: JonathanEdwards12
18.body:
Thank you for your follow-up.  The part of the article that most pertains to your case is towards the end where it has bullet-points on what happens after extractions.  The first point on the alveolar bone resorption with a video showing what happens when a tooth is extracted is the part that pertains to you.

The rest is relevant to the extraction of premolars followed by retraction to close the spaces.   None is relevant to you, except perhaps as you rightly perceived that any loss of alveolar bone and shrinkage of the dental arch can cause problems: especially but not only if braces are used to close the space and retract back the arch.

My concern in particular in your case is if the arch shrinks on one side, then you are left with an asymmetrical arch.   As you can tell from the article, anything that happens to the dental arches will affect the structure of the face.   An asymmetrical smile can result, as can one side of the mouth being a bit more inward than the other.  TMD can result if the occlusion force changes.

These are the worst case scenarios but I would never just let a space close, knowing what I know about how it can possibly cause  irreparable consequences.

.... just googled it and apparently...

'Today, both the United Kingdom and England are referred to as Igirisu (イギリス). The old name was Eikoku (英国). The ei (英) means something like 'outstanding' or 'excellent. ' This isn't because it was the country of knights and kings, but simply because of phonetics.'

20.author: mr_iwi

As a rugby playing nation I find it wild to hear that Japanese doesn't commonly use separate words for the British nations. Only about a dozen countries care about rugby and four of them are us!

England and Wales played each other in the FIFA world cup (November 29th 2022), I'm sure they would have been able to differentiate between the two teams. Maybe try looking for the result on the Japanese equivalent of bbc sport and see what they call Wales?

ウェールズ (U~ēruzu) is what I get from Google translate, but I have no knowledge of Japanese so whether this makes sense or not is another matter!

29.author: Double-Road639
29.body: Metadata is data that provides information about other data, but not the content of the data. Do you not know how metadata works? Smart meters connect to the internet the energy company recieves your usage and they can share your usage data to law enforcement etc to determine if your home or not. This is literally nothing new, like that channel i linked with the hacker showed off the smart meters firmware and what information is sent, this has been common knowledge that metadata is constantly harvested via the internet.

29.author: Double-Road639
29.body: Because british smart meters also sends usage to the energy companies and the grid which can be collected and your usage can be compiled to then determine if your home or not.

29.author: Double-Road639

My meter by british gas has a dashboard which has to connect to my wifi network and Data on 2G and 3G network is part of the internet as far as i'm concerned, that data they transfer over 2G and 3G mobile network is what i'm talking about, that can be harvested for metadata to determine if your home or not.

29.author: Double-Road639
29.body: I don't know the details but the content of the information isn't what is needed metadata is what is needed to determine if your home or not. All you need to determine if someone is home or not is when there is a demand for example when you turn your kettle on. This metadata can be harvested it's nothing new that NSA and GCHQ etc use prism and xkeyscore to evesdrop on civillians which are suspected to be terrorists or people of interest.

29.author: Double-Road639

38.author: schaweniiia
38.body:
Yes, that's what it means unfortunately.

I'm concerned about your stay here at the moment. If you have been here for more than six months without a visa, you're here illegally and you could mess up chances of ever gaining legitimate entry to the UK if you don't sort that out. Moving here without it makes you an illegal immigrant.

Please do yourself a favour and read up on this before you get in trouble. You are not allowed to just move here anymore unfortunately.

38.author: General-Amphibian663
38.body: If i’m living here as an illegal immigrant wouldn’t they have send me a warning or something to let me know that i’m staying here illegally? Also thank you for your help.

38.author: schaweniiia
38.body:
It's quite easy to become an illegal immigrant, just by overstaying your tourist visa. If you didn't tell them your aunt's address upon entry, then they simply might not know where you are and there are too many people who are doing this to be able to open a case against every individual illegal immigrant.

Your problem will be that you will not be able to find legal employment here without a visa, you won't be able to study or use the NHS, let alone any public services or benefits. If you leave the country, they'll know exactly how long you've been here and next time you try to come here on a tourist visa again, they possibly will not allow you to enter because they might not believe you come here for tourism.

The bigger problem is that if anyone specifically points you out to border police, you could be detained and made to leave the country on the spot.

I recommend you contact Citizens Advice immediately, you need to follow this up. They could ban you from re-entering the UK for up to 10 years.

38.author: General-Amphibian663
38.body: Ok thank you very much. The decision to come here was made without much talk so i’m pretty unprepared for this. The only thing i have with me is an pdf with the unique application number to my uk settlement scheme application and i also go to college because of that pdf.

38.author: schaweniiia
38.body:
No problem. In the meantime, maybe call these guys and give them your application number:

>EU Settlement Scheme Resolution Centre

>Telephone: 0300 123 7379

>From outside the UK: +44 203 080 0010 

>Monday to Friday, 8am to 8pm

>Saturday and Sunday, 9.30am to 4.30pm

>You can ask a question about the scheme on [GOV.UK](https://eu-settled-status-enquiries.service.gov.uk/start) - they'll reply within 5 working days.

Maybe they can give you a helpful answer already. Citizens Advice will guide you through all this as well, [that's where I have this information from](https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/immigration/problems-with-your-settled-status-decision/#:~:text=It%20can%20take%20some%20time,if%20you%20linked%20your%20applications.).

Good luck!

42.author: Tabbiecat5
42.body: I'm saying I don't think people in the UK have enough choice and should be better informed to help us all make the best choice. The state defining what marriage entails is repressive.

42.author: Big-Veterinarian463
42.body: What failer of choice do they have?

42.author: Tabbiecat5
42.body: What's not clear about what I've said?

42.author: Big-Veterinarian463
42.body: What choice do you think is being denied them?

42.author: Tabbiecat5
42.body:
Well with marriage being legally binding as the default people are denied to an extent the opportunity to make an informed choice about whether to make that legal comitment: there's an assumption that you'll want to enter into this specific legal agreement but little information offered as standard about what that comitment entails, and it's not very customizable if you want to set different boundaries eg relating to inheritance, how property should be divided in the event of separation, etc. And prenups which can mitigate this are viewed as unromantic, pessimistic, etc. People often aren't very informed about the whole thing and I would argue that this negates their consent.

Also as I said Christian ceremonies are viewed as the default, with civil ceremonies being arguably pseudochristian. And the state defines what is a valid ceremony and what isn't, for example excluding minority religious ceremonies such as handfastings, until recently refusing to recognise same sex spouses, currently refusing to acknowledge marriages that include more than two people. So marriage as an institution enforces particular relationship norms that don't work for everyone.

43.author: TinyLet4277
43.body:
Seems to mainly be just after the war, presumably a "right, country a bit of a mess, lets plan how we're going to rebuild and stake our place on the global stage through the next 50 years and beyond" attitude that was common at the time - lots of house building, creation of the NHS, etc.

Makes sense that there's such a big gap from all the (still excellent) resources so far - lots of the 1940s stuff is RAF/military stuff which is now public domain. From the 50s until the advent of the internet, aerial photography was a commercial, private, and quite expensive venture, hence why hardly any seems to exist. I had a mate who's mum had a few aerials of their house/farm on the walls as a kid. They weren't cheap.

43.author: TinyLet4277
43.body: That's bloody decent that - very high res photos. But quite "spotty" in terms of coverage and all largely centred around the war time, which I suppose makes sense.

43.author: TinyLet4277
43.body: Good suggestion, but looks to use the same 1945-49 photography you can get on Google Earth.

53.author: Cam2910
53.body:
>You can't hand in a notice and then force the company to keep you on longer

Resigning and handing in a notice can be different things though.

Sending: "please take this letter as notice of my resignation" would mean the notice period (if it isn't worded as a minimum notice period) would apply. If it is worded as a minimum you'd need to tell them when.

Sending: "i've secured a position in another company and my last day of work with you will be x." Is effectively "handing in your notice" in advance.

Which has been fine in all the jobs I've ever had.

53.author: FlappyBored
53.body: That’s not true. Resigning legally is viewed as the same as handing in a notice. If you are clear that you are wanting to end your employment then it can be taken as notice given.

53.author: Cam2910
53.body:
>If you are clear that you are wanting to end your employment

Even if you make it clear you only want to end your employment on a specific date?

I'm hoping to take up an academic course full time in the next few years. If I get a place and am successful I could know about it 6 months in advance.

You're telling me that if I told my employer in Mar that I was leaving in Sept they could just say nope you're leaving in 4 weeks?

53.author: FlappyBored
53.body: Yes, as you are confirming your intention to leave it can be counted as handing in your notice. Anything outside of whats written in your contract is down to both parties to agree to.

53.author: Cam2910
53.body:
You're wrong

https://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/work/resigning/your-notice-period-when-resigning/

>You can give more notice than your contract says, if you want - your employer can’t make you leave earlier.

53.author: FlappyBored
53.body:
That's talking about your notice period....

Your employer can't make you leave earlier than your notice period in your contract, not anything extra.

By all means try it if you want, no one will stop you.

53.author: Cam2910
53.body:
No it's talking about the notice that you give. 

>You can give more notice than your contract says, if you want - your employer can’t make you leave earlier. If they do make you leave earlier, this counts as sacking you. You should check if you can claim unfair dismissal.

If your contract states 4 weeks minimum and you give 12 weeks, they would need a valid reason to terminate your contract earlier than the 8 weeks (sack you).

55.author: GamerHumphrey
55.body:
Since you mentioned being self employed, a good self employed Software Engineer can be charging 600 per day, never having to leave the comfort of their own home. 

I hired a plumber this month at 70p/h. Let's say they're travelling for 2hrs a day to get between clients, and ignore fuel costs. A 8hr day becomes a 6hr day. That's only 420 before their deductions such as fuel, vehicle maintenance etc. 

A SE is earning considerably more when you put them in a similar situation.

55.author: GamerHumphrey
55.body:
"AI" as you're talking about it is many many years away from being a reality. It needs to be able to take a ton of requirements, be able to produce code that is extensible and easily maintainable, suitable for the use case, be able to change existing functionality when new requirements inevitably come in from the client after its already produced half of the project. Then it needs to update it in the future when another addition needs to be added which requires a rewrite of the existing code. 

Oh and then it needs to ensure its bug free, which it won't be able to do easily. 

Right now ChatGPT gets all its info from Pre-2021. That's 2-3 years of changes which its not accounted for. A lot changes in the dev world in 3 years.

64.author: ItsShaneMcE
64.body:
You don’t need to know the story. Both parents should be equally responsible for the finances of raising the kids regardless of where they reside.  

This “if I don’t see them, I ain’t paying” is a clear sign of a young or unintelligent mindset.  The kids don’t all of a sudden not exist because you’re not around them 24/7. They’re still your responsibility

Don’t like the situation. Take them back to court and fight your case. I know people that went from 12hrs supervised contact to 50/50 split because he challenged the courts decision and get this.  They sided with him because he was in a stable job and could prove he could provide adequate care so your “I’d quit before I paid them a penny” comment would be counter intuitive

64.author: alfiemorelos20
64.body: You’re not taking my kids and my wages.

64.author: ItsShaneMcE
64.body:
Can’t argue with stupid.  She didn’t take his kids. The government deemed her the more suitable parent therefore she didn’t take them. She was rewarded them by being the better suited parent.

10 years is a long time to not fight for more contact if that’s really what he wanted

Your comments all come from greed rather than love for a kid and I hope for your sake you grow out of it
